entry.title: Combined summary - overall bitcoin client code quality
entry.summary: In July 2011, the Bitcoin community engaged in a discussion about various aspects of the Bitcoin client codebase. Jeff Garzik suggested using "libbitcoin" and starting with a small module to implement in a branch. Matt Corallo discussed an alternative to using Berkeley db 4 by storing file offsets in an STL map. The group debated creating a chain description file for adjustable parameters and the importance of having clean, well-documented code. Luke-Jr suggested beginning a complete rewrite of the codebase, while Gavin Andresen proposed stopping Bitcoin usage for six months to implement a better client. The author argues that having 50-80 code files in Bitcoin may not be bad since it provides an easier-to-read history and fewer merge conflicts. Boost is an unnecessary dependency that should be replaced with lightweight alternatives. The Bitcoin codebase is in need of significant cleanup and reorganization to improve readability, reduce bugs, and make it a reference project for other clients. Improving the code quality is vital for the long-term success of the project.Michael Offel expressed concerns about the long build times for Bitcoin due to the use of boost, a lack of module isolation, and implementations in header files. Douglas Huff agreed with Offel's points and suggested they be addressed. Alan Grimes discussed how the one class-per .h/.cpp rule is being ignored in main.h/cpp and net.h/cpp. Jeff Garzik objected to refactoring all classes into separate files and suggested finding a balance between strict rules and putting logically similar code together.BitCoinJ has a useful NetworkParameters abstraction that groups constants together, making unit testing easier. In an email conversation, Michael Offel listed several areas that needed improvement in the Bitcoin client, including a lack of code documentation, poor use of threads, and hardcoded values. While Offel believed a complete rewrite was necessary, Garzik responded by saying there were limited development resources available.The Bitcoin codebase has been a topic of discussion among developers, with suggestions ranging from a complete rewrite to incremental improvements. Mike Hearn suggests a complete rewrite inspired by the old code, while Gavin Andresen advocates for incremental improvements. Jeff Garzik defends putting logically similar code together instead of splitting it into many tiny files. The use of constants in programming is discussed, including TCoinsElement MAX_MONEY, which appears to be a limit on the amount of coins that can be used in a particular program or application. One author expresses concerns about code quality in Bitcoin and suggests a plan for cleanup, including module isolation and better documentation. Another author faces difficulties in writing a bitcoin daemon due to design problems and suggests refactoring all classes into separate files. Alan Grimes objects to this suggestion, while Michael Offel believes every class should stand on its own. Discussions also include the need for consistent blockchain validation logic and testing rigs for new members to the project.In email exchanges related to Bitcoin, various suggestions and proposals were made to improve the code base. Mike Hearn suggested a complete rewrite of the code instead of just moving functional code around, which was supported by an old essay by Joel Spolsky. Another contributor agreed that refactoring would be helpful instead of reproducing every detail in a rewrite. Michael Offel proposed reimplementing parts as libraries and emphasized the importance of consistent implementation of blockchain validation logic across all nodes. Various topics were discussed, including the creation of a new library called 'libbtc', the usage of Db4 indexed database functionality, and hardcoded values for official and testnet block chains. Andy Parkins clarified the purpose of TCoinsElement MAX_MONEY constant, which appears to be a limit on the amount of coins that can be used in a particular program or application. Luke-Jr questioned its value, but Andy Parkins defended it and suggested that Luke-Jr might have misunderstood its purpose.
